information.title: Introduction of a Bill
information.description: A bill can be introduced in either house of Parliament. It can be introduced by a minister (government bill) or by any other member (private member's bill).

information.title: First Reading
information.description: The bill is introduced in the house. Its title is read out, and no discussion takes place at this stage.

information.title: Second Reading
information.description: This stage involves detailed discussion on the bill. It may be referred to a select committee for scrutiny. Amendments can be proposed and voted upon.

information.title: Committee Stage
information.description: If referred, the bill is examined clause by clause by the committee. The committee then submits its report to the house.

information.title: Third Reading
information.description: The bill is discussed as a whole. Only formal amendments are allowed at this stage. The house then votes on the bill.

information.title: Other House
information.description: If passed, the bill is sent to the other house where it goes through similar stages. If passed without amendments, it's sent for President's assent.

information.title: Joint Session
information.description: In case of disagreement between the two houses, a joint session can be called to resolve the deadlock.

information.title: President's Assent
information.description: After being passed by both houses, the bill is sent to the President for assent. Once signed, it becomes an Act.
